author: Peter Martin
title: Budget outlook dismal as private sector wage growth hits fresh all-time low
text:
Inside the banks' rubbery earnings reports 
Bloomberg Gadfly Columnist David Fickling reports on discrepancies in Australian banks' earnings reports. More videos Lower growth, less revenue 
Leading Australian economists are more pessimistic about the Australian economy than the official Treasury position. Peter Martin explains. 
The second consecutive record low is bad news for the Reserve Bank whose governor Philip Lowe expressed concern on Tuesday about wages and prices being stuck in self-perpetuating spira l. The official rate of inflation is also at a long-term low of 1.5 per cent. 
It's also bad news for the government which had been banking on a rebound in wage growth to boost tax revenue through bracket creep. The 2016 May budget forecast wage growth of 2.5 per cent for the year to June 2017, a figure revised down to 2.25 per cent in the December budget update. Related Content 'Difficult to ignore': RBA concerned about high household debt 
In the private sector the health care and social assistance industry and the education industry recorded the highest wage growth of 2.4 per cent, and the mining industry the lowest, of just 1 per cent. Wages in real estate grew by just 1.2 per cent and by only 0.2 per cent over the quarter. Advertisement 
Research by the Bureau of Statistics finds the average wait for a wage rise has nearly doubled over the past four years, blowing out from 12 months to 21 months. 
And the increases are getting smaller. The Bureau says the average increase received by workers who did get them has shrunk from 3.6 per cent to 2.3 per cent. SHARE
